msItem.p: Ioppe (Jaffa), likely third to fifth century CE. Limestone Tombstone. Funerary.

projectDesc.p: The Inscriptions of Israel/Palestine project seeks to build an internet-accessible database of published inscriptions from Israel/Palestine dated ca. 500 BCE to 614 CE. This timespan roughly corresponds to the Persian, Greek, and Roman periods. Our database will make accessible the approximately 10,000 inscriptions published to date and will include substantial contextual information for these inscriptions, including images and geographic information. We tag our data according to Epidoc conventions.

div.p:
Μνῆμα Τρύ
φωνος υεἱ
οῦ Μαρις
Ἀλεξανδρέ
ος Διαβενα
The memorial of Tryphon son of Maris, the Alexandrian, from Adiabene(?).

A white limestone tombstone with a reddish tint from Ioppe. The inscription is a Jewish tombstone. The editor notes that the first upsilon in the word υεἱοῦ is oddly shaped and has a dot above it, while the iota has two dots above it. It is uncertain if these dots have any meaning. The name The name Tryphon is of Greek origin and is common for both Jews and non Jews. The name Maris or Mari likely has a Semitic derivation and is frequently attested in Jewish epigraphy and rabbinic literature, but it is also used by non Jews. Maris is most likely of Semitic origin. The editor notes that the last line of the inscription is difficult to interpret and warns that the reading of Adiabene for ΔΙΑΒΕΝΑ is uncertain. An unclear symbol appears at the end of this last line, and likely representing more letters or the nature of the abbreviation. Another unclear symbol appears below the text. Assuming the interpretation given is correct, this inscription seems to indicate that Tryphon was originally (or ethnically) from Adiabene, lived (and probably had citizenship) in Alexandria, and finally was buried in Ioppe. The deceased in Iopp0004 is also identified as Alexandrian. Of the 80+ known Jewish epitaphs from the necropolis of Ioppe, as many as thirteen explicitly refer to Jews who seem to have come from Egypt, possibly indicating an Egyptian Jewish community in the city. The inscription makes use of lunate sigmas as well as large minuscule omegas (in place of their majuscule counterparts). Finally, the editor points out that if the stone had been found out of context (and if the unclear symbol on line 5 remained illegible) there would have been nothing to indicate that Tryphon was Jewish.
